questions.question_text: Which of the following can be used to perform online password attacks against RDP?

discussion.content:
D.Ncrack is a very fast password brute-force tool from the Nmap team. But it can only
be used for a limited set of protocols. As of this writing, here are some of the protocols
it supports:
• FTP
• Telnet
• SSH
• RDP
• VNC
• HTTP(S) (basic authentication)

Selected Answer: D
looks good to me
John is an offline cracker. the answer is D

D
Ncrack is used for cracking network authentications such as RDP.

John is more of an offline cracker

https://sushant747.gitbooks.io/total-oscp-guide/content/online_password_cracking.html
The Answer is B
Both John the Ripper and ncrack support RDP.

https://blog.2code-monte.co.uk/2020/08/02/cracking-password-hashes-hacking-rdp-servers-part-3/
B

questions.question_text: A penetration tester is reviewing a Zigbee implementation for security issues. Which of the following device types is the tester MOST likely testing?

discussion.content: B. this was on the exam
the answer is B

Selected Answer: B
looks good to me
wtf is this. every second answer is wrong. its IOT (B). bcz zigbee is used in smartlocks, smart bulbs etc
B. IoT

Answer is B:

Zigbee is a wireless technology developed as an open global standard to address the unique needs of low-cost, low-power wireless IoT networks. The Zigbee standard operates on the IEEE 802.15. 4 physical radio specification and operates in unlicensed bands including 2.4 GHz, 900 MHz and 868 MHz.

I'm not sure if it's B. according to reference it says : 
"
Routers in a Zigbee network act as intermediate nodes between the coordinator and the end devices.
Routers have to join the network first by the permission of the coordinator. Then they can route
2
traffic between end devices and the coordinator, as well as transmit and receive data. A router also
able to allow other routers and end devices to join the network. Similar to the coordinator, routers
also cannot sleep as long as the network is established[3]."
So if I had to test this kind of infrastructure probably I will start from Router... what do you think?
Answer is Definitely B....

questions.question_text: A client's systems administrator requests a copy of the report from the penetration tester, but the systems administrator is not listed as a point of contact or signatory. Which of the following is the penetration tester's BEST course of action?

discussion.content: D. I would leave the explaining to the POCs.. pentesters are often told not act as an authority..

comments.content:
i agree with your argument and want to add two that let me lean towards d:
1.) Maybe the System Administrator does not really know that a Pentest is Performed.
And just wants you to give hime confirmation that a pentest was confirmed.
2.) Service Quality ... the Company is still you customer so you want to make things easy for them.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
looks good to me

I'd go with C.
imagine everytime some unauthorized party requests the report, you sending it to the PoC...

C

The administrator probably isnt aware that the pentester cant just give the report to them, there is no harm in explaining that they need authorization.
I think is C

choices.A: Send the report since the systems administrator will be in charge of implementing the fixes.
choices.B: Send the report and carbon copy the point of contact/signatory for visibility.
choices.C: Reply and explain to the systems administrator that proper authorization is needed to provide the report.
choices.D: Forward the request to the point of contact/signatory for authorization.

questions.question_text: A penetration tester is planning to conduct a distributed dictionary attack on a government domain against the login portal. The tester will leverage multiple proxies to mask the origin IPs of the attack. Which of the following threat actors will be emulated?

discussion.content: APT attack against government

Selected Answer: B
sorry, I meant to vote for B, the Hacktivist

Selected Answer: A
looks good to me

comments.content:
considering "multiple proxies to mask origin ip" makes me lean towards 
b hacktivist.

discussion.content:
Hard one in my opinion: 
could be A,B or even C.
APTs are not only a Goverment Problem, every Company can be attacked by an APT if you have valuable information.
Goverments can be attacked APTs, Hacktivists and also angry script kiddies.
a Dictonary attack is a very basic Attack (Script kiddies)
Doing it from multiple Sources(Proxies) makes it more complex.

Apt's use (Zeroday)-Exploits and Phising to gain access. So a Dictonary attack does not emulate an APT. 

Considering that question what a dictonary attack "emulates" i would be just a script kiddie. 
Do Script kiddies attack goverments? Or would that be more a hacktivist?
Usure if B oder C.
It's B

PenTest+ Practice Tests Book - SYBEX

A. Black box tests, sometimes called zero knowledge tests, are intended to replicate what an attacker would encounter. Testers are not provided with access to or information about an environment, and instead, they must gather information, discover vulnerabilities, and make their way through a target (infrastructure or systems) as an attacker would.

comments.content: "Target list" could be something like "our web server"....no ip address or anything else...now write "his web server" on a sheet of paper.. place a 1. before words "His web server". Write words "Target list"(--note that words are not case sensitive--) above words" 1. his web server". Now answer the following questions...1.) Can a Web Server be a target? 2.)Is your sheet of paper a list? Now AND the statements(see cryptography, AND OR and XOR) Algorithm= YES/YES=YES, YES/NO=NO, NO/YES=NO. AND(YES)=TargetList while AND(NO)!=TargetList...WELCOME TO COMPTIA...GOOD LUCK

discussion.content: The correct answer is A. Black box testing provides very few details to the pentester.

Selected Answer: A
looks good to me

Selected Answer: A
I'm going with A as black box testing provides little to no information prior to.
A better answer would be NO INFORMATION
Answer is A please change it.
A also the reference link on the answer is according with A answer
A is the right answer.
Why on earth would D be correct that is comoletely contradictory to what black box means. This has to be A

100% would be A.
A black box is not having any information so the first step of recon would be what is it you're attacking.
A is the only answer here. D is 100% the wrong answer - no black box test would give credentials to the pen tester.
answer is A because everyone else said so

The hacker is not supposed to get any information from the client allowing him to do the job since it is the Black box, not all of the answers provided are correct, but answer A would be my choice for this case
A for sure.

comments.content: That has always been my understanding. Which would mean all the answers are wrong. But I would think that A is the least wrong. Typical CompTIA.

discussion.content: Its 'A' Black Box you get nothing !
A is correct answer.

questions.question_text: Black box penetration testing strategy provides the tester with:
